para.paratext: In Georgia, when a defendant contends that he has been aggrieved by an unlawful search and seizure, he should make a pretrial motion to suppress the evidence seized.
O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30 states:

(a) A defendant aggrieved by an unlawful search and seizure may move the court for the return of property, the possession of which is not otherwise unlawful, and to suppress as evidence anything so obtained on the grounds that:
The search and seizure without a warrant was illegal; or
The search and seizure with a warrant was illegal because the warrant is insufficient on its face, there was not probable cause for the issuance of the warrant, or the warrant was illegally executed.

(b) The motion shall be in writing and state facts showing that the search and seizure were unlawful. The judge shall receive evidence out of the presence of the jury on any issue of fact necessary to determine the motion; and the burden of proving that the search and seizure were lawful shall be on the state. If the motion is granted the property shall be restored, unless otherwise subject to lawful detention, and it shall not be admissible in evidence against the movant in any trial.

(c) The motion shall be made only before a court with jurisdiction to try the offense. If a criminal accusation is filed or if an indictment or special presentment is returned by a grand jury, the motion shall be made only before the court in which the accusation, indictment, or special presentment is filed and pending.

Although the motion to suppress must be in writing[1] and timely, the statute does not specify a time when the motion must be made. However, in Thomas v. State ,[2] the Georgia Court of Appeals adopted the federal approach codified in Fed. R. Crim. P. 41(e) requiring a motion to suppress evidence be made before the testimony begins if defendant knows of the unlawful seizure and has had an opportunity to present the question in advance of trial.[
3]

In overruling the trial court's denial of a motion to suppress filed prior to the docket call on the morning of trial, the Georgia Court of Appeals, in Collier v. State ,[4] clarified that a motion may be filed at any time prior to trial or before entering a written plea. However, in Stewart v. State ,[5] the appellate court noted that Collier was decided prior to the advent of the Uniform Superior Court Rules, which provide that “[t]he motion must be made at or before the defendant's arraignment and if not made at the proper time is waived unless the time for filing is extended by the judge in writing.”
[6] The court noted that this rule has evolved over time and that its purpose is to ensure fundamental fairness to all parties and those who must attend trial. Accordingly, “failing to file a timely motion to suppress amounts to a waiver of even constitutional challenges.”
[7] Thus, in Berry v. State [8 ] the defendant's motion to suppress, filed the day before trial and without a judicially approved extension, was untimely. Again in Clark v. State ,[9] the Georgia Court of Appeals relied on Stewart and Uniform Sup. Ct. R. 31.1 to conclude the defendant had waived his right to be heard on the allegedly unlawful seizure.

A defendant's failure to file a timely motion to suppress, as required by O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30, waives any objection to the evidence at trial.[
10] Thus, in Sloan v. State ,[11] the Court of Appeals held that where the defendant failed to file a timely written motion to suppress, he had waived any objection to evidence on grounds it was obtained by an illegal search and seizure and his oral motion to suppress evidence was properly denied by the trial court.

In Kilgore v. State ,[12] the Court of Appeals further held that a failure to object to the evidence at trial waived the denial of the motion to suppress. The Georgia Supreme Court subsequently reversed and held that the denial of the motion to suppress could be assigned as error on appeal, even though no objection was made to the evidence when it was offered at trial.[
13]

However, in the absence of an actual ruling on the defendant's motion to suppress by the trial court, the defendant does waive his right to contest the admissibility of the evidence on appeal if he fails to object when the evidence is offered at trial.[
14] Thus, it is not sufficient for the defendant merely to file the motion. If the motion to suppress is not considered by the court, the defendant must affirmatively object to the admission of seized evidence at trial to retain his right to contest its admissibility on appeal.[
15]

When the defendant files a motion to suppress, the trial court must hold an evidentiary hearing.[
16] In Peabody v. State ,[17 ] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that hearing evidence on a motion to suppress during the trial and in the presence of the jury was reversible error. The Supreme Court reversed noting that the trial judge had announced his intention at the beginning of the trial and the defendants did not object, thereby waiving complaint about not having the evidence presented outside of the jury's presence.[
18] Clearly, this was contrary to O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30.

Two years later, the Georgia Supreme Court upheld a trial court's decision to hold an entirely closed pre-trial hearing on a motion to suppress in Waller v. State .[
19] The United States Supreme Court reversed holding that the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a public trial applies to a suppression hearing.[
20] The court's closure of the hearing in Waller did not meet this test: (1) the party seeking closure must advance an overriding interest that is likely to be prejudiced, (2) closure must be no broader than necessary to protect that interest, (3) the trial court must consider reasonable alternatives to closure, and (4) the trial court must make findings adequate to support the closure.

The trial court's denial of a motion to suppress is not a final judgment subject to appeal by the defendant under O.C.G.A. § 5-6-34.[
21] A defendant may seek interlocutory review of an adverse ruling on a motion to suppress upon receipt of a certificate of review from the trial judge and timely application to the Court of Appeals.[
22] Otherwise, the defendant must wait until the conclusion of the trial to appeal an adverse ruling on his motion to suppress.

“When a defendant moves to suppress evidenced based on an illegal search, the State bears the burden of proving that the search was lawful.”
[23] However, if the evidence was not offered at trial, then an erroneous denial of a motion to suppress is harmless.[
24] If the motion to suppress is granted, the state may appeal pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 5-7-1.[
25 ] If the state does not appeal, then it must restore all property, unless it is illegal contraband, to its owner[26] and the evidence is not admissible against the defendant at trial.

Suppressed evidence may not be used against the same defendant in a subsequent prosecution.[
27] However, the converse is not true. A criminal defendant is entitled to move for reconsideration of a previously denied motion to suppress[28] unless the trial court's ruling has been affirmed by the Court of Appeals.[
29]

A motion to suppress is not an appropriate procedural vehicle for excluding evidence which was not physically seized during an unlawful search,[30] such as testimony from witnesses. In Baker v. State ,[31] Georgia Supreme Court held that the defendant could not suppress witness testimony under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30 because there was no search and, therefore, no claim of an unlawful search.

In Reid v. State, [32] a sheriff in a dry county searched defendant's premises and found liquor. The court held that the liquor should have been suppressed due to a defect in the search warrant, but the sheriff's testimony about finding the liquor could not be “suppressed” through this vehicle. Since defendant failed to object to the sheriff's statements at trial, his testimony was admissible.[
33]

The holding in Reid was based upon a technicality. Normally, testimonial evidence arising from an unlawful search is subject to exclusion. As the Court of Appeals explained in Reid , “[i]f an order [suppressing the physical evidence pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30] has been granted it affords a basis or ground for making the objection to the testimony.”
[34] However, “because testimony relating to seized physical evidence may be admissible for reasons not appearing from a motion to suppress, the trial court's grant of a motion to suppress the evidence does not [always] constitute a ruling that all testimony related to the seized evidence is inadmissible.”
[35]

One ruling, therefore, does not guarantee the result on the other. Relying upon Reid, supra, the defendant in Walker v. State [36] filed a motion in limine, rather than a motion to suppress, to exclude testimony describing the items seized in a search on the basis that it was obtained solely as the result of the unconstitutional search and seizure. The Court of Appeals reiterated that “[b]ecause the admissibility of testimony about property seized in a search is not tested by a motion to suppress under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30, which applies only to suppression of tangible physical evidence, a pretrial motion in limine may be employed to seek a ruling on the admissibility of the testimonial evidence.”
[37]

However, a motion in limine is not considered in isolation. Rather, Reid requires that a motion to exclude testimony related to seized physical evidence “be considered in the context of the trial court's related ruling on a motion to suppress the seized physical evidence, including any ruling that defects in the affidavit supporting the search warrant or in the warrant itself were waived where no timely motion to suppress was filed.”
[38]

In Walker, supra, the defendant's sole basis for exclusion of the testimony describing the seized physical evidence was his claim that the evidence was the product of an unconstitutional search. However, the defendant waived any right to claim that the underlying search was unconstitutional because he failed to file a timely motion to suppress the seized physical evidence and was not entitled to exclude testimony on the basis that it was the fruit of an unconstitutional search.[
39] Therefore, testimony describing seized physical evidence can be excluded upon a proper objection thereto, but only if a proper motion to suppress the physical evidence is granted by the trial court.[
40] It is irrelevant whether the prosecution actually seeks to introduce the evidence at trial.[
41]

Courts ruling upon the admissibility of evidence from intoximeter and radar devices have confronted the same technical dilemma. As the Georgia Supreme Court has noted, “[n]either sort of evidence (breath test or radar use) fits neatly within traditional concepts pertaining to the search for and seizure of tangible items of proof.”
[42] There can be no doubt that an officer's use of a radar speed detection device or intoximeter is not a “search” and does not result in a “seizure” of “tangible evidence.”

Georgia courts have concluded that procedural technicalities must yield to judicial economy which is best served by evidentiary challenges being presented by way of pre-trial motions, rather than at the time evidence is offered.[
43] Thus, in State v. Johnston ,[44] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that an accused may challenge the admissibility of the results of an intoximeter “breath test” either by way of a motion to suppress or by objection at the time the test results are offered as evidence. The Supreme Court subsequently affirmed that decision but added that “[t]he trial court is not bound by the nomenclature used by a party.”
[45] Although the defendant's motion was styled a “motion to suppress,” the trial court could treat it as a motion in limine.[
46]

Again in Wiggins v. State ,[47] the court held that objections to evidence from a radar speed detection device may be “raised by motion in limine, although the motion may be styled as, or in the form of, a motion to suppress, and that the trial court has discretion to hear the motion pre-trial or to reserve ruling on the admissibility of the evidence until it is offered as evidence during trial.”
This rule also applies to other “seizures” in a criminal investigation, which do not involve tangible physical evidence, and that evidence may be properly excluded regardless of the how the motion itself is captioned.[
48]
See also Taylor v. State, 118 Ga. App. 605, 164 S.E.2d 876 (1968); Peppers v. State, 144 Ga. App. 662, 242 S.E.2d 330 (1978).

Stewart v. State, 232 Ga. App. 565, 567, 502 S.E.2d 502 (1998) (quoting Hatcher v. State, 224 Ga. App. 747, 748–749, 482 S.E.2d 443 (1997)).
Berry v. State, 246 Ga. App. 9, 539 S.E.2d 516 (2000) .
Clark v. State, 248 Ga. App. 88, 545 S.E.2d 637 (2001).
Turner v. State, 170 Ga. App. 355, 317 S.E.2d 631 (1984); Sloan v. State, 172 Ga. App. 620, 323 S.E.2d 834 (1984).
Sloan v. State, 172 Ga. App. 620, 323 S.E.2d 834 (1984).
Kilgore v. State, 155 Ga. App. 739, 272 S.E.2d 505 (1980).
Kilgore v. State, 247 Ga. 70, 274 S.E.2d 332 (1981).
See Castillo v. State, 281 Ga. 579, 642 S.E.2d 8 (2007) (citing Bridges v. State, 263 Ga. App. 849, 589 S.E.2d 616 (2003)).
Castillo v. State, 281 Ga. 579, 642 S.E.2d 8 (2007); Judkins v. State, 282 Ga. 580, 652 S.E.2d 537 (2007).
Gray v. State, 145 Ga. App. 293, 243 S.E.2d 687 (1978).

But see Watts v. State, 261 Ga. App. 230, 582 S.E.2d 186 (2003), distinguishing Gray on the basis that O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30(b) does not require a trial court to procure evidence that is not tendered; it only mandates that the parties be given a full and fair opportunity to present evidence at a hearing which the trial court shall then receive. The prosecution cannot argue that no “evidentiary” hearing was held when it fails to tender evidence at a properly held suppression hearing.
Peabody v. State, 156 Ga. App. 853, 276 S.E.2d 47 (1980) .
State v. Peabody, 247 Ga. 580, 277 S.E.2d 668 (1981).
Waller v. Georgia, 467 U.S. 39, 104 S. Ct. 2210, 81 L. Ed. 2d 31 (1984).
Cody v. State, 116 Ga. App. 331, 157 S.E.2d 496 (1967).
See Genter v. State, 218 Ga. App. 311, 460 S.E.2d 879 (1995).
Lott v. State, 303 Ga. App. 775, 694 S.E.2d 698 (2010); State v. Brantley, 264 Ga. App. 152, 589 S.E.2d 716 (2003).
Stephens v. State, 119 Ga. App. 674, 168 S.E.2d 333 (1969).

The grant of a motion to suppress is only subject to direct appeal where the defendant claimed that the evidence was “obtained in violation of law.” See O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30. Thus, in State v. Brown, 185 Ga. App. 701, 365 S.E.2d 865 (1988), the state's appeal was dismissed where trial court's granted of defendant's motion, actually a pretrial evidentiary ruling (based upon the parties prior stipulation), rather than ruling on claim that evidence had been obtained in violation of law.
Cook v. State, 141 Ga. App. 241, 233 S.E.2d 60 (1977).

But see Kitchens v. State, 198 Ga. App. 284, 401 S.E.2d 552 (1991) (explaining that the Cook rule is inapplicable to rulings on confessions and in cases where the prior proceedings were subsequently set aside).
State v. Marcus, 206 Ga. App. 385, 425 S.E.2d 351 (1992).
State v. Slater, 214 Ga. App. 119, 446 S.E.2d 771 (1994).
Norrell v. State, 116 Ga. App. 479, 157 S.E.2d 784 (1967).
Reid v. State, 129 Ga. App. 660, 200 S.E.2d 456 (1973).
Reid v. State, 129 Ga. App. 660, 200 S.E.2d 456 (1973) . As to a confession. See Jarrell v. State, 234 Ga. 410, 216 S.E.2d 258 (1975).
Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 488, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006) (quoting Reid v. State, 129 Ga. App. 660, 663, 200 S.E.2d 456 (1973)).

See also Harridge v. State, 243 Ga. App. 658, 534 S.E.2d 113 (2000) (officer could testify he saw seized physical evidence in plain view even though the physical evidence seized without a warrant was properly suppressed).
Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006).

Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 488, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006).
Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006).
See Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006).

But see Bobo v. State, 153 Ga. App. 679, 266 S.E.2d 247 (1980) , where a motion to strike the testimony of the officer was properly granted, despite the absence of a motion to suppress, because the officer's testimony was based on his personal observations at the scene of the traffic stop and was not derived from seized physical evidence subject to a motion to suppress.
Walker v. State, 277 Ga. App. 485, 627 S.E.2d 54 (2006).
Wiggins v. State, 249 Ga. 302, 290 S.E.2d 427 (1982).
State v. Johnston, 160 Ga. App. 71, 286 S.E.2d 47 (1981); Wiggins v. State, 249 Ga. 302, 290 S.E.2d 427 (1982).

See, e.g., Thomas v. State, 287 Ga. App. 124, 124, 650 S.E.2d 793 (2007) (referring to the defendant's pre-trial motion as his “motion to suppress and/or motion in limine” ).
